author: By Callie Holtermann
title: How Similar Are You to the Adults Who Raised You?
description: What personality traits do you share with your parents and other family members? How do you feel about those similarities?
content: How much do you have in common with the adults who raised you?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: C.D.C. to Lift Order Restricting Immigration During the Pandemic
description: The change is to take effect in late May, according to people familiar with the planning, and should restore the right of migrants to request asylum once they cross the border into the United States.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is expected to lift a pandemic-related public health order this week that has restricted immigration for the past two years, a change that could more than double what is already a historic number of migrants surging into the United States from Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Call Logs Underscore Trump’s Efforts to Sway Lawmakers on Jan. 6
description: New details from White House documents provided to the House panel investigating the Capitol assault show a seven-hour gap in records of calls made by the former president on the day of the riot.
content: WASHINGTON — As part of his frenzied attempt to cling to power, President Donald J. Trump reached out repeatedly to members of Congress on Jan. 6 both before and during the siege of the Capitol, according to White House call logs and evidence gathered by the House committee investigating the attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley, Gabby Sobelman and Raja Abdulrahim
title: In Life, They Showed Israel’s Breadth. In Death, They Were Victims.
description: The five victims of Israel’s deadliest terrorist attack in years came from different walks of life, highlighting the complexity of Israeli society.
content: BNEI BRAK, Israel — At five minutes to eight on Tuesday evening, an Israeli teacher was on an evening stroll, pushing his baby son in a carriage. Up the street, a businessman was in his car, running a brief errand. Around the corner, two Ukrainian construction workers were chatting outside a popular convenience store. And a few blocks over, an Arab Israeli policeman was riding his motorcycle, keeping an eye out for trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC and Russia are set to meet as the war continues to roil the oil market.
description: Big producers seem to be sticking to modest output raises and alliance with Russia.
content: In the last month, oil markets have been shaken by a war that has sparked a jump in prices and threatened a critical shortfall in crude and other petroleum products.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Sloss
title: Where to Take the Waters: A U.S. Hot Springs Guide
description: Whether at a luxury spa or a more rustic natural environment, a dip in a natural hot springs promises to be relaxing, if not also medicinal. Here’s where and how to get started.
content: Even years later, I can call up the memory of easing into the piping hot, silty waters of Travertine Hot Springs in Mono County, Calif. Sliding in, I took a sharp intake of breath at the water’s steaming temperature, a contrast to the cold mountain air on my shoulders. I felt the squelch of mud between my toes and a gleeful relaxation of my muscles, taut and aching after days of hiking the Eastern Sierra Nevada range. As the golden glow of a late summer sunset gave way to a moonless, star-filled sky, I embraced an increasingly necessary, elusive sensation of absolute calm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Anna Netrebko Seeks Distance From Putin After Losing Work
description: The superstar soprano, whose past support of the Russian president cost her many engagements after the invasion of Ukraine, said in a statement that she was not “allied with any leader of Russia.”
content: Anna Netrebko, the Russian diva whose international career recently fell apart because of her past support of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, sought to distance herself from him Wednesday, saying they had only met a few times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Morris
title: Representation or Stereotype? Deaf Viewers Are Torn Over ‘CODA’
description: They’re hesitant to criticize the Oscar-winning film because it showcases deaf actors and lives, but some find its hearing perspective frustrating or even upsetting.
content: In many ways, the success of “CODA,” the drama about a deaf family with a hearing daughter, is a breakthrough moment for deaf audiences: The movie won best picture at the Oscars on Sunday night; its writer-director, Sian Heder, won best adapted screenplay; and Troy Kotsur took home the prize for best supporting actor, making him the first Deaf man to win an Oscar for acting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Oratorio for Living Things,’ the Song Is You
description: Heather Christian’s rapturous new music-theater work turns a tiny amphitheater into a vast cathedral of sound.
content: At the Academy of Music, where the Philadelphia Orchestra used to play, longtime subscribers were sometimes rewarded with a chance to move from floor-level seats to raised gilded boxes at the back of the horseshoe. After my parents took that step, my mother soon regretted the change. It’s true she saw the players better from above, but she’d felt them better from below, where the buzz of bassoons and the blast of tubas came through the wood directly to her feet, turning symphonies into seismic events.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 80-Car Pileup on Pennsylvania Highway Leaves 6 Dead
description: Several tractor-trailers were involved in the chain-reaction crash this week on Interstate 81, about 50 miles northeast of Harrisburg, Pa.
content: Six people were killed and two dozen others were injured in an 80-vehicle pileup on an interstate highway in Pennsylvania this week that began when a snow squall blinded drivers, the authorities said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laird Hunt
title: A Dazzling New Foray into Speculative Fiction From Emily St. John Mandel
description: In “Station Eleven,” she explored fallout from a pandemic. Now, in “Sea of Tranquility,” Mandel takes up existential questions of time and being.
content: Let’s begin with a moment of beauty, one of many in Emily St. John Mandel’s time-leaping sixth novel, “Sea of Tranquility.” It comes in the second half of the book, which is set in part in Earth’s far-off future, as a woman takes a commercial flight back to her home on the moon:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Poem (and a Painting) About the Suffering That Hides in Plain Sight’
description: Students will explore a famous poem by W.H. Auden on the nature of human suffering, written amid the gathering storms of World War II. They will then write their own ekphrastic poem.
content: Featured Article: “A Poem (and a Painting) About the Suffering That Hides in Plain Sight” by Elisa Gabbert
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mueller
title: Keep Getting Lost? Maybe You Grew Up on the Grid.
description: Childhood environments shape people’s navigational skills, researchers reported. The findings one day may lead to better tests for early dementia.
content: As a child in Chicago, Stephanie de Silva found that the city helped her get where she was going. Streets had directional names like “West” or “North,” and they often met at neat right angles. If all else failed, Lake Michigan could situate her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Aida Alami
title: U.S. Pressured to Open Consulates in Jerusalem and Western Sahara
description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken, on travels through the Middle East and North Africa over the past week, was urged by Arab leaders to make good on past promises.
content: RABAT, Morocco — In talks this week with the top American diplomat, Arab leaders made clear they wanted a concrete sign of the Biden administration’s support: the opening of U.S. consulates in both Jerusalem and the disputed territory of Western Sahara.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa
title: K-Pop Star Luna to Make Broadway Debut in ‘KPOP’ the Musical
description: The show, which had an Off Broadway run in 2017, will begin previews this fall at Circle in the Square Theater.
content: “KPOP,” a high-energy multimedia show about Korean pop stars, will transfer to Broadway this fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: A NASA astronaut will soon land on Earth in a Russian spacecraft. Here’s how to watch.
description: Although the U.S. and Russia have halted cooperation in many areas over the invasion of Ukraine, they’ve continued to work together aboard the International Space Station.
content: Early on Wednesday morning, Mark Vande Hei, like many NASA astronauts before him, entered a Russian spacecraft docked at the International Space Station for the return trip to Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Raphael Minder
title: Inflation in Germany and Spain reaches record levels, driven by Russia’s war.
description: The high price of energy is driving up consumer prices across Europe, with both Germany and Spain hitting record levels.
content: High energy prices and snarled supply chains drove up inflation in Europe, with Germany hitting a level not seen in more than 40 years and Spain setting a similar record, with prices soaring nearly 10 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Are You Receiving, Providing or Paying for Long-Term Care?
description: The New York Times and Kaiser Health News are looking into whether Americans have enough resources and help as they age.
content: As Americans live longer, it is increasingly difficult and expensive to ensure that older people receive the medical and personal help they need, whether at home or in a care facility. That includes assistance with getting up and about, bathing and taking medications. Likewise, older people with dementia or other cognitive issues need help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Flamingo No. 492 Is Still on the Run 17 Years Later
description: A fisherman’s sighting in March confirmed that a flamingo that fled a Kansas zoo in 2005 has defied the odds to live a Pixar-worthy life in the wilds of Texas.
content: On a windy day in Wichita, Kan., in 2005, No. 492 made its escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: For Grammy Nominee Rogét Chahayed, Pop Isn’t Far From Mozart
description: Up for producer of the year, non-classical, on Sunday, a conservatory-trained collaborator focuses on “finding the simplicity, finding that golden chord progression.”
content: Two very different kinds of education went into the music that has brought Rogét Chahayed a 2022 Grammy nomination for producer of the year, non-classical. One was traditional music school: the San Francisco Conservatory of Music, where Chahayed studied classical music and jazz and earned a degree in piano performance. The second was a studio apprenticeship of late nights and split-second decisions: playing keyboards and building beats for the Los Angeles hip-hop mogul Dr. Dre.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Has Fun With Trump’s Missing Phone Records
description: “The only time there should be a seven-hour gap is when you’re trying to remember what happened on St. Patrick’s Day,” Jimmy Fallon said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soyica Diggs Colbert
title: ‘Told It Like It Was’: Ntozake Shange’s Tales of Black Womanhood
description: As ‘For Colored Girls’ returns to the New York stage, we look at how the show found its way from a Bay Area bar to Broadway in 1976.
content: Ntozake Shange’s “For Colored Girls Who Have Considered Suicide/When the Rainbow Is Enuf” defied Broadway conventions when it opened at the Booth Theater on Sept. 15, 1976. An experimental “choreopoem” focusing on the lives of seven women of color, who are each named after colors of the rainbow, was revelatory and not something you might expect to find on a mainstream Broadway stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seema Jilani
title: Why So Many Doctors Treat Their Mental Health in Secret
description: The culture of medicine means no crying, no sleeping, no making mistakes. And no getting help.
content: Certain memories are seared into physicians’ psyches. The chirp of the pager. Driving home half asleep in a postcall haze. The strangest objects found in human orifices (cockroach in the ear). The most hours we continuously stayed awake. Delivering our first baby, watching our first patient die. These are all rites of passage. I’ve found it’s easy to discuss the funny memories, but the disturbing ones are harder. Even with the closest of friends, recounting the tough moments feels like passing on a burden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman and Michael Gold
title: New York City Clears 239 Homeless Camps. Only 5 People Move to Shelters.
description: In the subways, nearly 80 people a week accepted shelter over a four-week period, Mayor Adams said. Officials have not yet said how many stayed off the street.
content: Results so far are mixed on New York City’s effort to move homeless people out of the subway system and street encampments and into shelters, Mayor Eric Adams said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: President Dissolves Tunisia’s Parliament, Deepening Political Crisis
description: President Kais Saied, who suspended Parliament last year, dismissed that body after lawmakers challenged the autocratic powers he has exercised.
content: Tunisia’s president dissolved Parliament on Wednesday, after lawmakers voted to block emergency powers he had given himself last year, trying to harden his sole grip on the government and courting what could be the country’s severest political crisis since the 2011 revolution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Do I Need Another Booster?
description: And President Biden presses for aid as the country moves on.
content: The F.D.A. authorized second boosters for Americans aged 50 and older and those with certain immune deficiencies on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salman Masood and Christina Goldbaum
title: Defection of Key Ally Gives Opposition the Votes to Oust Imran Khan
description: Without the support of Muttahida Qaumi Movement-Pakistan, the country’s prime minister will lose the simple majority needed to survive Parliament’s no-confidence vote.
content: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan — Days away from a no-confidence vote in Parliament, Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan is facing mounting pressure after a key ally in his political coalition joined the opposition on Wednesday, giving his opponents the votes required to remove him from office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: How Aphasia Steals the Ability to Communicate
description: Bruce Willis will retire from acting after being diagnosed with the condition. Here’s what we know about it.
content: Bruce Willis, the film star known for his roles in “Die Hard” and “Pulp Fiction,” will step away from his decades-long movie career in the wake of a recent aphasia diagnosis. His ex-wife, Demi Moore, shared the news in an Instagram post, saying the disease was “impacting his cognitive abilities.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Your Favorite Tree
description: Do you have a favorite tree, or favorite species of tree? What and why?
content: Do you have a favorite tree, or a favorite species of tree? If so, what and why? How has it played a role in your life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Does the End of Cash Mean the End of Privacy?
description: A new bill in Congress says anonymity can be preserved.
content: As cash disappears from the modern economy, privacy disappears with it. You can’t spend money with a credit card, debit card or check without creating a record of your transaction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: The Nuclear Family Is No Longer the Norm. Good.
description: Our society is making room for different family structures.
content: Over 20 years ago, the sociologist Vern Bengtson gave a lecture in which he predicted that multigenerational bonds would be ascendant in the 21st century. Bengtson, who spent decades studying generations of 300 California families, pushed back against the idea that the decline of the nuclear family model was bad for society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gary He
title: How a Restaurant, and our Photographer, Overcame Omicron
description: Gary He spent three months embedded in a New York City restaurant, Saigon Social, to capture what it faced during the Omicron surge. In the process, he redefined what it meant to be a regular.
content: On a chilly Saturday in early December, I stood on a corner on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, snapping photos of a restaurant across the street. A pack of intoxicated men dressed as Santa Claus, participating in an annual costumed bar crawl, stumbled into my frame. I gave chase with my camera, trying to line them up for a photo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Spider Friends, ‘Firefall,’ Grief Camp
description: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.
content: Each Wednesday we shine a spotlight on five student activities that support a broad range of learners. In this week’s roundup of accessible activities, we invite students to learn about a new species of spider, think about something amazing they’ve seen in nature, watch a film about young people dealing with grief, share how they feel about mask mandates ending and look closely at a photograph.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: A Casino Atop Saks? Lobbyists Push for Manhattan Gambling Site
description: State lawmakers are weighing whether to fast-track a move to allow three new casinos in the New York City area, as part of this year’s budget negotiations.
content: A Monaco-style casino atop Saks Fifth Avenue, across the street from St. Patrick’s Cathedral. A gambling den with East River views, alongside a popular wedding venue. A Hard Rock casino in the center of Times Square.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Richard Lipez, Who Reimagined the Gay Detective Novel, Dies at 83
description: Under the pen name Richard Stevenson, he sought to correct crime fiction’s portrayals of gay characters as freaks or villains with an entirely relatable protagonist.
content: Richard Lipez, the author of a series of crime novels centered on an openly gay detective who, unlike the one-dimensional depictions common in the genre in the 1980s and ’90s, is not a tortured soul or a freak but a relatable character who is content with his life, died on March 16 at his home in Becket, Mass. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalia Winkelman
title: ‘Trust No One: The Hunt for the Crypto King’ Review: Coins and Misdemeanors
description: In this sensationalist Netflix documentary, aggrieved users of a defunct cryptocurrency exchange grow convinced that the company’s head absconded with their money.
content: Like a garden-variety con man, “Trust No One: The Hunt for the Crypto King” relies on razzle-dazzle to deflect from an emptiness of insight. The documentary (on Netflix) centers on Gerald W. Cotten, the founder of a Canadian cryptocurrency exchange called Quadriga CX who died in 2018, leaving many users shut out from accessing their funds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ai-jen Poo and Ilana Berger
title: We Need More Home Care Workers. But First We Have to Pay Them Enough.
description: A plan for higher home care wages under consideration in New York State could offer a model for how we can care for older people.
content: Loretta Copeland, an 81-year-old who lives in Harlem, uses a wheelchair and depends on an aide to help her with daily tasks like cooking and bathing. But New York’s home care labor shortage, currently the worst in the nation, has made it hard for her to get help. While she understands why people won’t work for such low wages, she is afraid she will end up in a nursing home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: California Task Force Votes to Offer Reparations Only to Descendants of Enslaved People
description: The decision came after weeks of debate about whether all Black Californians should receive reparations.
content: California is one step closer to determining who could receive reparations from the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: The Brilliance of Charo
description: The guitarist, singer, actress and comedian has long wrapped her prodigious talents in a glossy, over-the-top persona. Decades later, she’s still going strong, and it’s time to take her seriously.
content: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — Charo was on. As soon as the gate to her Spanish colonial compound swung open, she was buzzing around the property, a gaggle of staff trailing somewhat helplessly behind as she delivered a running monologue studded with self-deprecating jokes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: After Russia Invaded Ukraine, a U.S. Nonprofit Shifted Its Mission
description: Spirit of America was focused on helping counter Russian propaganda but now is sending helmets, Kevlar vests, radios and vehicles to Ukraine.
content: WASHINGTON — Jim Hake began working in Ukraine in 2015, the year after Russia annexed the Crimean Peninsula. His nonprofit, Spirit of America, supplied medical kits to the Ukrainian military and assisted U.S. programs to counter Russian propaganda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: A Tap-Dancing Soul in Spirit-World Limbo
description: In “Once Upon a Time Called Now,” the tap dancer and musician Michela Marino Lerman tries something new: a theatrical narrative.
content: The tap dancer Michela Marino Lerman is an outstanding jazz musician. In recent years, she has made a place for herself in jazz clubs not always hospitable to hoofers or female players. The shows that her band, Love Movement, performed at the Whitney Museum in 2019 were truly movements of love, parties overflowing with good vibes and brilliance. But for her debut at the Joyce Theater, she’s trying something new: a 90-minute theatrical narrative, “Once Upon a Time Called Now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxana Popescu
title: House Hunting in Costa Rica: Pools, Ponds and a Glassy Heart Near San José
description: As tourists return and residency laws change, the country is seeing more demand along its Pacific coast, with the Centra Valley lagging behind.
content: This six-bedroom villa sits in a gated community in Costa Rica’s Central Valley, just west of San José, the capital. Built in 2012 on three lots spanning 1.28 acres, the single-story house covers more than 17,000 square feet, weaving outdoor spaces into and around the layout as patios, terraces and water features.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Goldberg
title: Everyone Is Not OK, but Back at Work Anyway
description: Supervisors are called on to help people navigate personal challenges, whether or not they have the training to do so.
content: It’s exceptionally difficult to get someone to crack a smile, let alone laugh, in a corporate event hosted on Zoom, but the comedian Dani Klein Modisett finds ways. One game she likes to play during her laughter workshops involves asking participants to each name five items in a category — for example, things in their refrigerator — as fast as they can, after which everyone else chants: “Those are five things!” Eventually people loosen up. They start giggling. (Maybe you had to be there.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Bound by a Sense of Victimhood, Serbia Sticks With Russia
description: Moscow, despite its invasion of Ukraine, remains a lodestar for nations like Serbia that feel resentment and grievance against the West, experts say.
content: BELGRADE, Serbia — Mindful of the angry and still-unhealed wounds left by NATO’s bombing of Serbia more than 20 years ago, Ukraine’s ambassador appeared on Serbian television after Russia invaded and bombed his country in the hope of rousing sympathy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: From Unemployed to a Champion, Perhaps
description: Wesley Matthews does the little things for the Milwaukee Bucks. “We talk about trying to make everything difficult,” said Coach Mike Budenholzer.
content: PHILADELPHIA — After spending last season with the Los Angeles Lakers and the first few weeks of this season out of work, Wesley Matthews returned to the Milwaukee Bucks in early December. The day after he signed his new contract, he found himself coming off the bench for the team in a lopsided win over the Miami Heat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Bosman and Sophie Kasakove
title: States Close Mass Test and Vaccine Sites, but Virus May Swell Anew
description: Officials say demand has slowed as coronavirus cases have fallen. But some experts question the scaling back of services, especially vaccination campaigns.
content: CHICAGO — As Americans shed masks and return to offices and restaurants, local and state officials are scaling back the most visible public health efforts to address the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden gets his second booster after his Covid remarks.
description: It came after federal health officials cleared an additional booster dose of Pfizer-BioNTech or Moderna vaccines for people over 50 and for many of those who have compromised immune systems.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden received a second Pfizer-BioNTech booster shot against the coronavirus on Wednesday afternoon, a day after federal health officials cleared an additional booster dose of Pfizer or Moderna vaccines for people over 50 and for many of those who have compromised immune systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Ivermectin Does Not Reduce Risk of Covid Hospitalization, Large Study Finds
description: “At some point it will become a waste of resources to continue studying an unpromising approach,” one expert said.
content: The anti-parasitic drug ivermectin, which has surged in popularity as an alternative treatment for Covid-19 despite a lack of strong research to back it up, showed no sign of alleviating the disease, according to results of a large clinical trial published on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Thursday Briefing: Mixed Signals from Russia
description: And Israel tightens security after a rash of shootings, while young, rag-tag rebels fight the Myanmar junta.
content: Pessimism is replacing optimism over Ukraine, as Russia sends mixed military and diplomatic signals. After seeming progress in Tuesday’s peace talks in Istanbul, Wednesday brought new attacks on the outskirts of Kyiv and the northern city of Chernihiv, areas where Russia claimed it would reduce combat operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: New York Weighs a Gas Tax Holiday, a Popular ‘Bad Idea’
description: With deadlock on many major issues, a proposal to provide relief to motorists has picked up steam.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — In the final feverish days of state budget negotiations, there are few things that New York State lawmakers seem to agree on. One of them is that gas prices are too high.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Bruce Willis Has Aphasia and Is ‘Stepping Away’ From His Career
description: The news of his diagnosis, initially announced by his ex-wife, Demi Moore, prompted an outpouring of support and appreciation for Willis from fans, stars and other notable figures.
content: Bruce Willis, the prolific action-movie star, has been diagnosed with aphasia — a disorder that affects the brain’s language center and a person’s ability to understand or express speech — and will step away from acting, his ex-wife, Demi Moore, announced in an Instagram post on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cade Metz
title: Turing Award Won by Programmer Who Paved Way for Supercomputers
description: In the 1970s, Jack Dongarra created code and concepts that allowed software to work easily with the world’s most powerful computing machines.
content: In the late 1970s, as a young researcher at Argonne National Laboratory outside Chicago, Jack Dongarra helped write computer code called Linpack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Tyler Hicks
title: ‘Like Living in a Horror Movie’: A Ukraine Town Dying a Slow Death
description: The war never stops in Huliaipole, a town on the front lines in eastern Ukraine. Most residents have fled. Those who remain listen to the Russian shelling and wonder: Where will the next one land?
content: HULIAIPOLE, Ukraine — The shelling begins in earnest a little before midnight, well after the sky has turned oily black, the cell towers have powered down and the stray dogs have begun barking into the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Spam Texts From Your Own Number? ‘Bad Actors’ Sent Them, Verizon Says.
description: The wireless carrier said that it was working with the F.B.I. and the Secret Service to investigate a recent wave of fraudulent messages, but said the source did not appear to be Russian hackers.
content: The wireless carrier Verizon blamed “bad actors” on Wednesday for thousands of spam text messages recently received by its customers and said it was working with federal law enforcement agencies to try to identify the source.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling and Julia Jacobs
title: Will Smith Refused to Leave Oscars After Slap, Academy Says
description: The film organization revealed that Smith was asked to leave the Academy Awards after slapping Chris Rock, as the comic addressed the incident for the first time at a show in Boston.
content: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said Wednesday that the actor Will Smith was asked to leave the Oscars ceremony after he slapped Chris Rock onstage Sunday night, but that the actor refused to go.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Austen
title: Ex-Chief of Canada’s Military Pleads Guilty to Obstruction in Sex Misconduct Case
description: The investigation that led to charges against Jonathan Vance, a former chief of Canada’s defense staff, is one of several that have ensnared current and former Canadian military commanders.
content: OTTAWA — Canada’s former top military commander pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice on Wednesday in connection with a military police investigation into allegations that he engaged in sexual misconduct while leading the country’s military.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx and Katherine Schulten
title: A Special Poetry Challenge: What Small Kindnesses Do You Appreciate?
description: We’re doing something new for National Poetry Month: inviting you to contribute lines for a collaborative poem on the theme of kind acts.
content: What minor, gracious things do others do for you that make you happy?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: What We Know About the Women Who Vote for Republicans and the Men Who Do Not
description: What distinguishes the people who fall on the wrong side of the gender gap?
content: The deepening gender gap in American voting, with men favoring the Republican Party and women favoring the Democrats, is well known, if not well understood. So what explains the presence of millions of men in the Democratic Party and millions of women in the Republican Party? What distinguishes these two constituencies, whose partisanship runs against the grain?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: The ruble makes a strong showing after peace talks.
description: The ruble’s stronger showing is most likely driven by artificial factors and might not be a good marker that the Russian economy is improving, one expert said.
content: Propped up by positive expectations that were bolstered by peace talks in Istanbul and by the Russian central bank’s quick and robust measures to support it, the Russian ruble made a staggering rebound approaching its prewar value on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Underneath It All, She’s 100% Lizzo
description: The Grammy-winning singer releases her newest venture: shapewear.
content: The many, many people who have applauded, criticized and otherwise taken part in what often seems like an endless discussion around Lizzo’s naked form may be surprised to learn that she does not spend quite as much time undressed as they may think.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘The Square,’ ‘Sorry to Bother You’ and More Streaming Gems
description: This month’s offbeat streaming recommendations include several very dark satires, a handful of engaging indies, and two documentaries that cinephiles will adore.
content: The Swedish director Ruben Ostlund follows up his pointed social satire “Force Majeure” with this arch, uproarious and bitter attack on the pretensions of the art world. He adds a few famous faces to the mix (including Elisabeth Moss and Dominic West), but his biting voice has not been tempered — if anything, he cranks up the blatant discomfort and inescapable embarrassment. That doesn’t sound like much fun, granted, and at times it is not. Yet Ostlund’s refusal to soften (or redeem) his characters is admirable, and if you have the right kind of darkly comic sensibility, it’s a deeply funny piece of work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: How the Ukraine War Gave Fracking in the U.K. a Second Chance
description: Russia’s invasion has disrupted the global energy market and led to higher prices across Europe. That has reopened the debate in Britain over shale gas extraction.
content: LITTLE PLUMPTON, England — There’s not much left of Britain’s only operable fracking site, which was mothballed in 2019 when it caused earth tremors so strong that they were felt miles away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Battle for Donbas
description: Russia appears to be focusing more on eastern Ukraine. That’s both good and bad for Ukraine’s military.
content: When Russia began its invasion of Ukraine on Feb. 24, Vladimir Putin and his inner circle were not the only people who expected a rapid Russian march to victory. Many independent observers did, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: Curious About ‘Moon Knight’? Here’s What You Need to Know.
description: Starring Oscar Isaac and Ethan Hawke, the new Marvel series follows a troubled, crime-fighting caped crusader. But don’t mistake him for Batman.
content: If you’re a connoisseur of superhero comics, you probably know Moon Knight, the supernaturally empowered, mentally unstable vigilante played by Oscar Isaac in the new Disney+ Marvel mini-series that bears the character’s name, debuting Wednesday. But if you’re more of a casual fan, you may have missed out on this very strange superhero, even though he’s been fighting crime — and his inner demons — since the 1970s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick McGeehan
title: International Tourists Flock Back to New York, With One Big Exception
description: Chinese tourists are still barred from traveling abroad. But city officials forecast a 70 percent increase in tourism in 2022, including 8 million visitors from abroad.
content: After two years of sparse crowds in Times Square and other popular attractions, New York City is finally hoping for a robust rebound of visitors this year. But the city will still be missing a main driver of its prepandemic tourism boom: big spenders from China, whose government has yet to allow travel abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes, Lara Jakes and John Ismay
title: U.S. intelligence suggests that Putin’s advisers misinformed him on Ukraine.
description: One American official said that there “is now persistent tension” between the Russian president and his Defense Ministry.
content: WASHINGTON — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has been misinformed by his advisers about the Russian military’s struggles in Ukraine, according to declassified U.S. intelligence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeannette Catsoulis
title: ‘Nitram’ Review: Slouching Toward Infamy
description: In this unnerving drama based on a true crime, a lonely outsider reaches his breaking point.
content: The most chilling scene in Justin Kurzel’s “Nitram” — a movie that’s rarely less than freezing — occurs near the end and shows the title character, a disturbed young man, buying multiple firearms and rounds of ammunition. His demeanor is, for the first time, confident and purposeful; his handling of the weapons as natural as if he were born to them. The scene unnerves even if we don’t know where he’s going, because we know where he has been.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: A Democratic Super PAC’s Ad Buy Shows a Widening Battle for House Control
description: The Democrats’ House Majority PAC is spending nearly $102 million to reserve advertising time in 51 media markets, staking out a broad battlefield for the coming midterm elections.
content: WASHINGTON — The House Democrats’ main political action committee is spending nearly $102 million to reserve advertising spots in 50 media markets, from Bangor, Maine, to San Diego, Calif., a battlefield that is considerably larger and more expensive than it was in the past two congressional elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins
title: We Can’t Get Even Regular Gun Control. How Are We Going to Deal With Ghost Guns?
description: Let’s be thankful that Biden has gotten started.
content: Mark this on your April calendar: Joe Biden does something about ghost guns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: If Dogs Played Wordle
description: Dogs like to do what we do. So it’s only a matter of time, right?
content: Here at Gameplay, we are all about the science. Whether it’s digging into the psychology of why ENO appears so often in the New York Times Crossword (something about airports), or seeing how much sugar the digital puzzles editor Sam Ezersky can eat before he loses the ability to solve a puzzle (this really happened), Gameplay is on the job. Just imagine us wearing white lab coats and glasses that make us look like intellectuals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Adam Dean
title: Driven From City Life to Jungle Insurgency
description: Fleeing the military’s brutal crackdown, Myanmar’s newest rebels have abandoned cafes and professions to join a near-daily battle with long odds.
content: On jungle crests about a mile from the front lines in eastern Myanmar, a former hotel banquet coordinator slipped his index finger onto the trigger of an assault rifle. A dentist recalled picking larvae from a young fighter’s infected bullet wound. A marketing manager described the adapted commercial drones she is directing to foil the enemy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Democrats’ Defense of Ketanji Brown Jackson Leaves Some Wanting More
description: Naming a Black woman to the Supreme Court was a major step for racial progress. It was also a missed political opportunity for President Biden, critics of the White House say.
content: As Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson solidifies support for her bid to become the first Black woman to join the Supreme Court, Democrats are still debating an enormously complex and weighty topic: how to talk about race in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Bazelon
title: What Message Did Republicans Send to Judges in Their Attack on Ketanji Brown Jackson?
description: Republicans ignored widespread agreement among judges about sentencing guidelines.
content: Few crimes carry more social opprobrium than child sexual abuse. Last week, several Republican senators, among them a few thought to harbor presidential ambitions, tried to capitalize on that stigma. They went after Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson, President Biden’s nominee for the Supreme Court, for sentencing decisions she made in cases involving child sexual abuse images during her eight years as a Federal District Court judge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: A Tiny Brontë Book, Lost for a Century, Resurfaces
description: A miniature book made by the 13-year-old Charlotte Brontë, to go on sale next month for $1.25 million, contains what may be her last unknown poems.
content: The miniature books created by Charlotte Brontë and her siblings as children have long been objects of fascination for fans and deep-pocketed collectors. Initially created to entertain their toy soldiers, the tiny volumes reflected the rich imaginary world they created in the isolation of the family home on the moors of northern England, which fed into novels like Charlotte’s “Jane Eyre” and Emily’s “Wuthering Heights.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Casino Bonanza May Soon Hit New York
description: The Legislature is likely to permit three casinos in the New York area, and Mayor Eric Adams wants the city to get two of them.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at the odds for casinos in Manhattan. We’ll also look at how the all-but-extinct American chestnut tree is making a comeback in a city park.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The People Who Draw Rocks’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about cartographers in Switzerland who document melting glaciers. Then, they will use maps to learn about the effects of climate change where they live.
content: Featured Article: “The People Who Draw Rocks” by Zoey Poll
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: New A.L.S. Treatment Lacks Evidence of Benefit, F.D.A. Panel Finds
description: With a 6-4 vote, the group of independent advisers to the agency narrowly concluded that results from another clinical trial are needed to assess whether the therapy, called AMX0035, can help patients.
content: By a narrow margin, a federal panel of independent medical experts concluded Wednesday that there is not yet enough evidence that an experimental therapy for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, commonly known as A.L.S., is effective in treating the devastating and fatal neurological disorder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: Yes, There Is a Clash of Civilizations
description: What Samuel Huntington foresaw about the current world order.
content: In 1996 the political scientist Samuel Huntington offered several strong claims about the post-Cold War world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Will the Ukraine War Spell the End of Globalization?
description: The seams of the global economic order were deeply frayed by the pandemic. Could this conflict cause it to unravel?
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Wednesdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Rob Szypko, Rikki Novetsky, Chelsea Daniel, Mooj Zadie, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Marc Georges, M.J. Davis Lin, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The Political Lives of Clarence and Ginni Thomas
description: How the Supreme Court justice and his wife came to be at the heart of the conservative movement.
content: A series of text messages released in the past week show how Ginni Thomas, wife of Justice Clarence Thomas of the Supreme Court, urged White House officials to push to overturn the result of the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Democrats Agree to Pay $113,000 to Settle Campaign Spending Inquiry
description: Hillary Clinton’s campaign and the Democratic Party described payments to a law firm that commissioned scrutiny of Trump-Russia ties — leading to the Steele dossier — as legal services, not opposition research.
content: WASHINGTON — Hillary Clinton’s 2016 presidential campaign and the Democratic Party have agreed to pay $113,000 in fines to settle a Federal Election Commission investigation into whether they violated a campaign finance disclosure law when they funded an opposition research effort into Donald J. Trump and Russia that resulted in a discredited document known as the Steele dossier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: House Republicans Tire of Madison Cawthorn’s Antics. Some in His District Have, Too.
description: For Mr. Cawthorn, a pro-Trump North Carolina congressman,  youthful brashness that helped him win his seat now strikes some voters as recklessness.
content: HENDERSONVILLE, N.C. — In the era of Donald Trump’s takeover of the Republican Party — when making falsehoods about an election isn’t disqualifying, when heckling a president at the State of the Union is no big deal, when attending an event tied to white supremacists doesn’t lead to exile — it may still be possible for a hard-right member of Congress to go too far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Minnesota Woman to Repay $120,000 Raised in Philando Castile’s Name
description: The Minnesota attorney general’s office said most of the money Pamela Fergus raised to pay off students’ lunch debt was not used as intended.
content: A Minnesota woman has agreed to repay $120,000 that she collected in an online fund-raiser named in honor of Philando Castile, the Black motorist killed in 2016 by a police officer during a traffic stop, after she was accused of failing to use the money for its intended purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris
title: ‘I Just Want Something That’s Gay and Happy’: L.G.B.T.Q. Romance Is Booming
description: Sales of queer romance novels have surged, with books coming from the biggest publishers and prominently displayed at mainstream retailers.
content: For years, Lana Popovic Harper wrote novels for a pittance she described as “jars of pennies.” So when her new project drew bids from seven publishers, she was thrilled. Stunned, really: The book was a romance about two women. Two women who happen to be witches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: implore
description: This word has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word implore has appeared in 27 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 7 in “Doing ‘The Washing Machine’ With My 84-Year-Old Mother” by Erika Shimahara:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Collins to Back Jackson for Supreme Court, Giving Her a G.O.P. Vote
description: Senator Susan Collins, a centrist from Maine, said a second meeting with Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson alleviated her concerns. It is unclear if other Republicans will join her.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Susan Collins of Maine plans to vote to confirm Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson to the Supreme Court, ensuring that President Biden’s nominee and the first Black woman to be put forward for the post will receive at least one Republican backer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski, Megan Specia and Julian E. Barnes
title: Russia Steps Up Attacks Amid Reports of Rifts in Moscow
description: Despite claims of de-escalation, Russian forces turned their fury on Chernihiv and the suburbs of Kyiv. U.S. officials say they believe Vladimir Putin’s aides are misleading him about the war.
content: Belying its claims of de-escalation, Russia increased bomb and artillery attacks in Ukraine on Wednesday and sent conflicting signals about the prospects for peace, suggesting new tensions in the Kremlin hierarchy about the course of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Americans are taking fewer precautions two years into the pandemic, a poll says.
description: As the United States entered its third year of the pandemic, fewer Americans are reporting that they have been wearing masks in recent months, according to a poll released on Tuesday by The Associated Press and NORC.
content: As the United States entered its third year of the pandemic, fewer Americans are reporting that they have been wearing masks in recent months, according to a poll released on Tuesday by The Associated Press and NORC.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Peace talks between Russia and Ukraine.
content: Peace talks between Russia and Ukraine provided some hint of progress yesterday, even as an imminent end to the suffering remained elusive. Ukrainian officials said the country was ready to declare itself permanently neutral and forsake the prospect of joining NATO.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: Have a Wedding Budget? Expect to Spend More Because of Inflation.
description: Florists, makeup artists and other vendors say that cancellations and supply-chain shortages caused by the pandemic have forced them to raise their prices.
content: Courtnie Alvear-Beceiro and Alex Klebba set aside $15,000 for their upcoming wedding on May 21.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tom Mashberg
title: Bust From the Met Museum, Said to Be Looted, Is Returned to Libya
description: Investigators said the sculpture, a depiction of a veiled woman, had been stolen decades ago from a temple at Cyrene, which was once part of ancient Greece.
content: Looters and vandals have for decades blighted Cyrene, a coastal city that was once a port of ancient Greece and is now a part of Libya. Two products of the pillaging, marble busts stolen from the city’s famed burial grounds and recently seized by investigators, were returned to Libya on Wednesday by the Manhattan district attorney’s office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Tornado in Northwest Arkansas Injures 7 and Destroys Part of a School
description: At least two people were critically injured by the storm system, which destroyed an elementary school gymnasium in Springdale, Ark., officials said.
content: At least seven people were injured, two critically, when a tornado touched down in northwestern Arkansas early Wednesday morning, damaging buildings, knocking out power and displacing residents, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Bubola
title: Family’s Balcony Death in Switzerland Appears to Be Suicide, Police Say
description: The investigation suggests that the victims jumped from the seventh-floor balcony “one after the other,” the police said.
content: The four members of a French family who were found dead at the bottom of an apartment building in a Swiss resort town last week appear to have jumped off a balcony, “one after the other,” as part of a group suicide, the Swiss police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Wander Franco Knew Exactly Where He Was Headed
description: When he arrived in Tampa as a 20-year-old phenom, Franco already had an M.L.B. logo tattooed on his neck. That he would stick around was a foregone conclusion.
content: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — The first thing you notice, up close to Wander Franco, is a tattoo of the Major League Baseball logo on the left side of his neck. Franco already had it last June 22, when he made his debut for the Tampa Bay Rays, as if he was pre-certified for stardom. Over the winter, he got the date inked above the emblem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Julia’ Review: Mastering the Art of Playing Julia Child
description: The celebrated British actress Sarah Lancashire follows in the footsteps of Dan Aykroyd and Meryl Streep in a biographical dramedy from HBO Max.
content: Two actors have given substantial portrayals of Julia Child, each excellent in its own way: Dan Aykroyd, bleeding all over a defenseless chicken on “Saturday Night Live,” and Meryl Streep, swanning through the 2009 film “Julie & Julia.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope and Knvul Sheikh
title: A New Wave of Covid-19 Is Coming. Here’s How to Prepare.
description: Taking these seven steps now can lower your risk and minimize the disruption to your family’s life.
content: The next wave of Covid-19 is coming, and in some parts of the United States, it’s already here. Are you ready?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Washington
title: I Got Lost in Tokyo Station and Found the Perfect Comfort Food
description: Kakuni (braised pork belly) is velvety and heartening, heightened by its directness — and wildly simple to cook.
content: Every dish exists in its own continuum, but they become interconnected through our personal experience. You eat a meal that blows your mind. That dish works its way into your life. One year, you go heavier on the garlic. The next, a little lighter on the char. Or maybe you grow to prefer more chile, more lime, more heat, until a meal’s history becomes interlocked with your own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Soda and Beer Companies Are Ditching Plastic Six-Pack Rings
description: In an effort to cut down on plastic waste, packaging is taking on different forms that can be more easily recycled or that do away with plastic altogether.
content: The plastic rings ubiquitous with six-packs of beer and soda are gradually becoming a thing of the past as more companies switch to greener packaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Haley Willis and Sarah Kerr
title: A new satellite image shows food lines in Mariupol, as Russian forces push deeper into the city.
description: The city has been under siege for weeks and is suffering from severe food and water shortages.
content: New satellite imagery released by U.S.-based space technology company Maxar Technologies shows hundreds of people lining up outside a supermarket in the southern Ukrainian city of Mariupol on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Saif Hasnat
title: Bangladesh Sentences 4 to Death for Blogger’s Murder
description: The victim, who had promoted secularism, was among several writers fatally attacked in the country in 2015.
content: DHAKA, Bangladesh — A special tribunal in eastern Bangladesh announced on Wednesday that four men had been sentenced to death for the 2015 murder of a blogger and writer who had promoted secularism in the Muslim-majority country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 30, 2022
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, March 30, 2022.
content: An article on Wednesday about Ukrainian counterattacks against Russian forces misstated the amount of money that Prime Minister Mario Draghi of Italy said his country had frozen in Russian assets. It was 800 million euros, which is the equivalent of about $900 million, not $900 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Roach
title: If You Think Kale Is ‘So 2010,’ You’re Not Growing the Right Ones
description: When it comes to kale, the organic farmers at Adaptive Seeds have a few things to teach you — and some versions of the familiar green that may not be so familiar.
content: Yes, Sarah Kleeger knows: Kale is not exactly making headlines these days. Not anymore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Hubble Space Telescope Spots Oldest and Farthest Star Known
description: Its light twinkled some 900 million years after the Big Bang, astronomers say.
content: Star light, star bright, how far you look tonight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: A Mural Lionizing an Indian Ruler Was Sold at Auction. His Legacy Is Contested.
description: The battle scene depicts a victory over British troops by an 18th-century Muslim, a man India’s current government would prefer was forgotten.
content: The mural shows Indian cavalry troops advancing from both sides on a cornered British army, guns blazing. In one part of the 18th-century battlefield, the victorious commander sits on an elephant holding a red rose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: A Russian negotiator’s positive language clashes with the hard-line rhetoric from Moscow.
description: The mixed messages underscored the lack of clarity over President Vladimir V. Putin’s goals in the invasion.
content: ISTANBUL — Russia’s lead negotiator said on Wednesday that peace talks with Ukraine appeared to be on the verge of a breakthrough, even as other officials voiced skepticism and pro-Kremlin commentators heaped scorn on the talks — mixed messages that underscored the lack of clarity over President Vladimir V. Putin’s goals in the invasion and the uncertainty over whether progress in the talks was real.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Perri Ormont Blumberg
title: How Married ‘Bachelor’ Couples Make it Work. Yes, Some Are Still Together.
description: As “The Bachelor” franchise enters its 20th year, still-married couples who met on that show and “The Bachelorette” discuss how they’ve built lasting relationships.
content: In the latest season of “The Bachelor,” Clayton Echard, the show’s 26th lead, said after a late-night rendezvous with a hopeful suitress, “If I ever need validation to know that this process works, I’m seeing it unfold before me.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $630,000 Homes in Louisiana, California and Ohio
description: An 1893 house outside New Orleans, a two-bedroom bungalow in Tujunga and an Edwardian home in Cincinnati.
content: Mandeville, on the north shore of Lake Pontchartrain, was once a rural escape for New Orleans residents who could afford to build second homes there. Until the construction of the Lake Pontchartrain Causeway in the mid-1950s, they traveled by steamboat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: They’ve Got Each Other’s Backs Now
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, March 30, 2022.
content: “We didn’t aspire to get signed. We thought it would not be in the cards. We just wanted to play some silly songs.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Ukraine Made Big Tech Pick a Side — But Who Are the Losers?
description: The Russia-Ukraine war has made clear, yet again, the dominance that platforms like Apple, Facebook and Google have. Is it time we finally take away that power?
content: Technology defines nearly every facet of our modern world. It almost feels that to exist today in the Western world, one has no choice but to engage in it. As a result, Big Tech holds an incredible amount of power — power that continues to play a role in the Russia-Ukraine war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: 9 Who Blocked Abortion Clinic Are Charged With Federal Offenses
description: Prosecutors said the defendants had used their bodies, furniture, chains and ropes to block the doors to an abortion clinic in Washington in 2020 and had livestreamed their actions on Facebook.
content: Nine people who blocked access to an abortion clinic in Washington in October 2020 have been charged with federal civil rights offenses, prosecutors said on Wednesday, about six months after the Justice Department signaled it would use a 1994 law to prosecute such cases across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: We Want to Publish Your College Application Essay About Money
description: If you applied during the 2021-22 school year, please send us your essay about money, work, social class or related issues. If we publish yours, we’ll pay you.
content: We don’t talk enough about money, nor do people very often write about it with nuance and emotional resonance. You, however, may be an exception. If so, we’d like to read your work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gretchen Reynolds
title: Can Moving the Body Heal the Mind?
description: In her new book, Jennifer Heisz blends personal experience and the latest science about how exercise can improve your mental well-being.
content: When Jennifer Heisz was in graduate school, she borrowed a friend’s aged, rusty road bike — and wound up redirecting her career. At the time, she was studying cognitive neuroscience but, dissatisfied with the direction of her work and her personal life, began experiencing what she now recognizes as “pretty severe anxiety,” she told me recently. Her friend suggested biking as a reprieve. Not previously athletic, she took to the riding with enthusiasm, finding it “soothed my mind,” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Bee Team
description: Jack Murtagh does some elision.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — It’s a welcome return to the New York Times Crossword for today’s constructor, Jack Murtagh! This is his third appearance in The Times, and his puzzle is a little tricky. In fact, it contains so many tricky clues that I’m going to dive straight into them after two quick housekeeping notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Want a Value-Priced Gadget? Good Luck.
description: More Americans than ever are buying fancy phones and laptops. Will it last?
content: By choice or necessity, Americans have fallen for fancier smartphones, televisions, laptops and cars. The companies that make this stuff are trying to assess whether the shift to luxury is a temporary phenomenon or a new normal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Spring Is Here! Here’s How to Spot the Seasonal Scams.
description: Along with the annual wave of tax-related phishing attempts, fake Ukrainian war-relief charities are flooding the internet.
content: Fraud is a year-round activity, but tax season brings an uptick in calculated schemes to steal money and personal information through spoofed messages and other means. Cybersecurity firms have also reported an increase in fraud attempts that exploit the conflict in Ukraine — a situation that has increased fears of potential cyberattacks on American companies through ransomware and other malicious software. You can better protect yourself if you know what’s out there. Here’s a guide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Hess
title: When the Master of the Erotic Thriller Fails to Thrill
description: Adrian Lyne used to make deranged romps animated by conservative masculine anxieties. By the time of “Deep Water,” his muse — the all-powerful white man — had lost his grip.
content: Recently I rented a house upstate for the weekend with a group of friends, all new parents with children under 2. After putting the children to bed, we decided to stage a group viewing of “Deep Water” on Hulu — then spent the next 15 minutes in a state of escalating madness, frantically tossing baby books and upending couch cushions in search of the house’s lost remote control. This was how desperate we were to feel like adults, and to experience a now-rare form of grown-up entertainment: an erotic thriller directed by the master of the genre, Adrian Lyne.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Borscht to David Foster Wallace
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: I HATE BORSCH! by Yevgenia Nayberg. (Eerdmans, $17.99, ages 4 to 8.) A girl who detests the national dish of Ukraine while growing up in Kyiv (she’s “Robinson Crusoe, stuck on a deserted island of sour cream in a red sea”) craves it when she moves to America, in Nayberg’s bold, expressionistic fairy-tale homage to her native land. A recipe is included.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Ashton Hawkins, Manager of the Rich and Powerful at the Met Museum, Dies at 84
description: A top executive, he cultivated donors, then used his legal acumen to arrange their multimillion-dollar gifts of money and art.
content: Ashton Hawkins, who was, officially, the executive vice president and counsel to the trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but who could more aptly be described as the chief curator of its vast collection of rich and powerful donors, died on Sunday at an assisted living facility in White Plains, N.Y. He was 84.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jaeah Lee
title: This Rap Song Helped Sentence a 17-Year-Old to Prison for Life
description: Rap music is increasingly showing up as evidence in criminal trials.
content: Tommy Munsdwell Canady was in middle school when he wrote his first rap lyrics. He started out freestyling for friends and family, and after two of his cousins were fatally shot, he found solace in making music. “Before I knew it my pain started influencing all my songs,” he told me in a letter. By his 15th birthday, Mr. Canady was recording and sharing his music online. His tracks had a homemade sound: a pulsing beat mixed with vocals, the words hard to make out through ambient static. That summer, in 2014, Mr. Canady released a song on SoundCloud, “I’m Out Here,” that would change his life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Modern Love Podcast: Right Swipes, Big City
description: A young woman with a prosthetic leg navigates dating apps in New York City.
content: Alexandra Capellini, a medical student in her mid-20s, has been on the dating apps for about four years. Dating is already a fraught process, but to top it off, Alexandra has to decide if, when and how she should explain that she wears a prosthetic leg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum

author: By Sarah A. Topol
title: The Battle for the Mural — and the Future of Belarus
description: It started as an act of graffiti at a playground in Minsk. It turned into a remarkable campaign of defiance against an increasingly totalitarian regime.
content: As his family slept, the man spent his nights planning. There were about 40 security cameras among the three buildings in central Minsk, maybe even more. He had long ago calculated their blind spots. He knew there was only one place in the shared courtyard they didn’t see. It took him a day to map out the best approach. The group had decided that they would act in the evening, when there would be enough people on the street so that their actions would not arouse suspicion but not so many that someone would be likely to report them to the police. He wasn’t afraid for himself as much as for the rest of them. If they got caught, it would be his fault.

content: DAKAR, Senegal — Hundreds of passengers on a train, many regular commuters traveling north from Nigeria’s capital of Abuja to the thriving city of Kaduna, were just minutes away from their final destination on Monday evening when they felt a bump and the train came to a stop.

author: By Will Heinrich
title: Richard Tuttle: Please Touch!
description: Whether you call “What Is the Object?” an exhibit or a collection, the display at Bard Graduate Center is utterly dependent on the good faith of its visitors.
content: The easiest way to describe “What Is The Object?” at the Bard Graduate Center would be to call it a single work of occasional art by the American post-Minimalist Richard Tuttle. Alongside his nearly 60 years of making delicate sculptures and wall works, Tuttle has been a collector of miscellaneous objects that catch his fancy, from an 11th-century brass candlestick made in the Bavarian city of Augsburg to a 19th-century Shaker darning knob with an appealing, egglike shape. And now that he’s donating more than 70 of these curios to the Bard Graduate Center — whose students of material cultural history will know how to take care of them — Tuttle, working with its dean, Peter N. Miller, has designed a display, complete with whimsical, multicolored wooden tables and a few of his own recent collages, to share the collection with the public.

content: It was as dark a time as Broadway had ever seen. Multiple stages were shuttered, uncertainty abounded, and a beleaguered theatrical season was limping along, desperate for a hit. But then a Hollywood movie star — who was also a uniquely magnetic performer on the musical stage — rode into town, bestriding a vehicle perfectly suited to his outsize talents. He had retreated to a film career for nearly a decade, and frequently hinted at a Broadway return, but then, in his 50s, he finally did so — and it didn’t hurt that a beloved musical comedy ingénue was at his side.

title: The Discovery of Shackleton’s Wreck Is as Disquieting as It Is Amazing
description: The world today is smaller and less mysterious than when Endurance sank. At the same time, we know too much about the past to be nostalgic.
content: Sometimes history speaks in rhyme. On March 5, 1922, the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton was buried in a hillside cemetery on the island of South Georgia, in the frigid far southern reaches of the Atlantic. Recently, a team of marine archaeologists announced that it had located the long-sought wreck of his famous ship, Endurance, a three-masted schooner barque that sank off Antarctica more than a century ago. The ship was found on March 5, 2022 — exactly 100 years after Shackleton was laid to rest.
